awd_titl_txt: Inactivation of Legionella pneumophila harbored by amoebae using a nano-enabled alternative technology: Application and outreach to the Colonias in Texas
awd_abstract_narration:
Legionnaires' disease is a deadly form of pneumonia caused by the bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila. Several outbreaks of this waterborne disease have occurred in the U.S. since 1976, and new cases have been growing at a high rate.  Exposure occurs when contaminated water droplets are inhaled (e.g., during showering) or aspirated. L. pneumophila can be harbored by free-living single-celled organisms (amoebae), which can shield L. pneumophila from traditional disinfection like a 'Trojan horse', thereby increasing risk for the spread of Legionnaires' disease. This project aims to develop a low-cost disinfection technology that can harness low-energy microwave radiation to inactivate L. pneumophila in drinking water. The work includes a major outreach program with the Texas colonias, or self-built communities, which are home to 400,000 low-income people, many of whom lack access to high quality drinking water. Successful development of this technology has the potential to ensure safe drinking water for the colonias and the Nation. 

The goal of the proposed irradiation-based technology is to generate interfacial heat and reactive oxygen species (ROS) to inactivate L. pneumophila harbored by amoebae. Amoebae will be lysed via interfacial heating, and the released L. pneumophila will be inactivated by heat and ROS. The proposed research will deploy fundamental nanoscience to develop a point-of-use (POU) and community-scale water treatment technology.  The specific technical objectives of the proposed research plan are to (i) synthesize, characterize, and test MW-harnessing nanomaterials, (ii) understand the mechanisms of microbial inactivation by this MW-based nanotechnology, and (iii) engineer two devices containing immobilized nanomaterials to effectively inactivate L. pneumophila harbored by amoebae. The research will capitalize on the scientific advantages of novel MW spectral conversion to provide safe drinking water to low-income residents of the Texas colonias and beyond. Outreach activities will occur in elementary schools and colonias located in three school districts (two in El Paso County and one in Hidalgo County, both of which have high concentrations of colonias). Hands-on educational activities related to the research will be conducted in the schools, and water sampling and household surveys will be conducted in the colonias to gather information on water quality, water use, water-related health issues, and socioeconomic conditions. The outreach is unique because the information it yields will be utilized in the device design, thereby enabling the development of a socially-embedded technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most common waterborne disease outbreaks in the U.S. since 1976 is due to the opportunistic human pathogen Legionella pneumophila.  Exposure occurs when contaminated water droplets are inhaled or aspirated. Such exposure to L. pneumophila can cause Legionnaires' disease, which is a severe and deadly form of pneumonia. Over the past decade, the number of reported cases of Legionnaires' disease has quadrupled in the U.S.  L. pneumophila can be harbored and protected from disinfection by free-living amoebae, which are resistant to traditional disinfection processes. Overall, the association between amoebae and L. pneumophila presents an increased risk for the spread of Legionnaires' disease, which must be addressed by the development of alternative disinfection techniques.

The main goals of this project were twofold:  (1) to develop and test an alternative technology using low-intensity microwave radiation coupled with silver (either Ag+ or silver nanoparticles, AgNPs) to inactivate L. pneumophila harbored by amoebae; and (2) to develop this disinfection technology so that it is not only effective but also capable of being socially embedded in the colonias along the Texas-Mexico border and other low-income regions.

 Intellectual merit

In this project, an alternative disinfection technology consisting of microwave radiation combined with silver (Ag+ or AgNPs) exposure was developed and tested for its effectiveness against L. pneumophila.  Microwave radiation combined with silver (particularly Ag+) appears to be a promising treatment for L. pneumophila inactivation, especially in overcoming the increased resistance provided to those L. pneumophila being harbored by free-living amoebae. 

The project demonstrated that free-living amoebae not only protect L. pneumophila but also condition L. pneumophila for increased treatment resistance and infectiousness upon egress.  Interestingly, this "protozoan-priming" phenomenon can be simulated by exposing free L. pneumophila to mM concentrations of magnesium. Overall, when assessing the effectiveness of a disinfection technology, it is critical to test the appropriate form of L. pneumophila (i.e., protozoan-primed).

Broader impacts

The Texas colonias (self-built communities) are home to 400,000 people of Hispanic descent with little or no service of potable water.  Furthermore, the warm temperatures of Texas make this region of colonias along the Texas-Mexico border particularly susceptible to an outbreak of Legionnaires' disease.

This project engaged with multiple colonias communities in three Texas border counties (i.e., El Paso, Starr, and Nueces). The project team not only conducted detailed water quality analyses and household surveys for these communities - to identify critical water issues and the underlying causes - but also carried out outreach activities in a number of middle and high schools in the region. The unique water quality issues and water-use practices identified through these studies will pave the way for continued technology development and future adoption in these low-income border communities.   

Results from this project were disseminated to the scientific community.  Three journal papers were published, with another journal manuscript currently under revision after peer-review.  Additionally, ten conference presentations and one Ph.D. dissertation were produced.

Two graduate students, twelve undergraduate students, and one high school student contributed to the research and/or the colonias outreach program, representing significant diversity with respect to gender, race, ethnicity, and economic status.
